statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Kerry Kittles cooled off after a hot start, but Jason Kidd just kept getting better.
article.headline: Nets ride Kidd's triple-double to victory

images.name: Kidd, Jason 020131 inline
images.caption: The Nets, led by early MVP favorite Jason Kidd, right, have opened up a five-game lead on the Celtics in the Atlantic.

article.linkText: Kidd, Nets thump Bucks in battle of East leaders
article.story:
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) -- Jason Kidd and the New Jersey Nets not only made a statement, they also heard one. "M-V-P! M-V-P! M-V-P!" Kidd recorded his league-best fourth triple-double with 21 points, 13 assists and 10 rebounds and the Nets embarrassed Milwaukee at the start and the finish in defeating the Bucks 125-100 Thursday night in a matchup of the top two teams in the East. The point total was the Nets' highest of the season and allowed them to snap a five-game losing streak against the Bucks that dated to March 18, 2000. It was also the Bucks' biggest loss of the season. "We're legitimate," Scott said. "We are one of the better teams in the Eastern Conference. We will have many more games like this with a playoff atmosphere. "They (the Bucks) came in here with a purpose," Scott said. "They wanted to make a statement. They wanted what we have right now, the best record." The Nets' 30-14 record is the best in the conference, and the win total is four more than they had last season. Without a doubt, Kidd had been the difference. He's taken a talented team that has stayed healthy this season and turned it into a contender. "Their guys were all here last year, and they were terrible last year," said Milwaukee guard Ray Allen, who was limited to 15 points by three early fouls. "But then you add him to the team and you have what they had out there tonight." It was a team that embarrassed the Bucks (27-17) in handing them their fourth loss in five games. Kerry Kittles had 20 of his 21 points in the first quarter of the matchup between the leaders of the Atlantic and Central Divisions. Todd MacCulloch added 20 points and 11 rebounds. Kenyon Martin had 14 points and a couple of monster slams, and rookie Richard Jefferson came off the bench to add a career-high 21 points. "They've been there before," Kidd said of the Bucks, who lost the conference final in seven games to Philadelphia last season. "They know what it takes to be successful. For us, there's no statement. This is for us to get better and learn." If the Nets do that, they will be challenging for more than the best in the conference at the end of the season. "My feeling is somewhere down the line we're going to meet them in a seven-game series," Scott said. Glenn Robinson came off the bench to lead Milwaukee with 23 points, while Sam Cassell added 19. "We beat ourselves tonight," said Cassell, a former Net. "They tricked us all night with simple stuff, and that shouldn't happen to a team like this." The Bucks, who beat the Nets handily in Milwaukee earlier this season, got into trouble early as New Jersey hit 12 of its first 14 shots and opened a 41-22 lead. Milwaukee got back into the game by outscoring New Jersey 28-14 in the second quarter to pull to 57-54 at the half. However, Keith Van Horn hit two big 3-pointers at the start of the third quarter to open a 63-54 lead. The Bucks got within four points but MacCulloch hit two layups, Kidd made a finger roll and Van Horn hit a short jumper to push the lead to 11. Milwaukee never got closer than seven points the rest of the way. New Jersey broke the game open in the fourth quarter as Kidd made a steal and layup and hit a 3-pointer in a 13-1 run to open the period. As Kidd walked off the court late in the game, the crowd chanted M-V-P! M-V-P!" "I thought they were spelling Nets," Kidd quipped after his 42nd career triple-double, which tied him with Fat Lever for fifth best all-time. "I did hear someone saying it when I was shooting free throws and I started laughing. That's something way down the line and not on my mind." The Nets have won seven in a row at home, where they are 17-4 this season. Game notes
The Nets' 43 first-quarter points matched their season high, which came in a blowout over Michael Jordan and the Wizards. It was also the most given up by the Bucks in a quarter. Their previous high was 40 against Atlanta on Jan. 18. ... Cassell was in the bathroom at the tipoff and didn't start for the first time in 41 games this season. The Nets 11 wins in January tied a franchise mark for wins in a month.
